headline: OpenAI reaches new agreement with Microsoft to change its corporate structure
summary: OpenAI has reached a new tentative agreement with Microsoft and said its nonprofit, which technically controls its business, will now be given a $100 billion equity stake in its for-profit corporation.  The maker of ChatGPT said it had reached a new nonbinding agreement with Microsoft, its longtime partner, “for the next phase of our partnership.”  The announcements on Thursday include a few details about these new arrangements.

raw.headline: OpenAI reaches new agreement with Microsoft to change its corporate structure
raw.summary: OpenAI has reached a new tentative agreement with Microsoft and said its nonprofit, which technically controls its business, will now be given a $100 billion equity stake in its for-profit corporation.  The maker of ChatGPT said it had reached a new nonbinding agreement with Microsoft, its longtime partner, “for the next phase of our partnership.”  The announcements on Thursday include a few details about these new arrangements.

headline: Mag 7 Stocks Are About to Be a $20 Trillion Market Problem
summary: Shares of Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla together had a market cap of $19.88 trillion, as of yesterday's close.  Collectively they are worth more than the entire GDP of every country except for the U.S., according to Dow Jones Market Data.  Currently the S&P 500 market cap is $55.896 trillion, which means Mag 7 makes up 35.9% of the index.

headline: Microsoft resolves European Union probe into Teams
summary: European Union regulators have accepted Microsoft's proposed changes to Teams, resolving a long-running antitrust investigation that targeted the company's messaging and videoconferencing app.  The European Commission said in a statement Friday that Microsoft's final commitments to unbundle Teams from its Office software suite, including further tweaks following a market test in May and June, are enough to satisfy competition concerns.  The legally binding commitments will remain in force for up to 10 years and allow the company to avoid a potentially hefty fine.

raw.headline: Microsoft resolves European Union probe into Teams
raw.summary: European Union regulators have accepted Microsoft's proposed changes to Teams, resolving a long-running antitrust investigation that targeted the company's messaging and videoconferencing app.  The European Commission said in a statement Friday that Microsoft's final commitments to unbundle Teams from its Office software suite, including further tweaks following a market test in May and June, are enough to satisfy competition concerns.  The legally binding commitments will remain in force for up to 10 years and allow the company to avoid a potentially hefty fine.
